Identification.BriefDescription: a document dated 21st January 1908 recording the sale of the Kursaal and and ongoing business to Walter Claude Johnson by 'The Prudential Assurance Company and Others'; a typed copy of the original conveyance, its importance is in the fact that it recites the history of ownership, mortgages and charges for building the Kursaal on De La Warr Estate land in Bexhill; included are names of DLW Estate trustees, mortgagees, and building contractors; amounts lent and payable are quoted; on page 10 is a list of the ten deeds for the property held by the Prudential Assurance Company; the document was probably well used for reference by the solicitors; certain paragraphs are marked in pencil at the side, some words underlined; page 9 gives details of an undertaking by the Earls De La Warr not to be involved with any other entertainment or refreshment business within a certain area beyond the Kursaal for 25 years; a coloured plan to scale of the site of the property is attached to the first page; copy issued by Whale and Wates, solicitors for Mr. Johnson; numbered 14 in an unknown sequence; witnesses of the Seal for the Prudential Assurance Company were two Directors and a Joint Secretary; other detail gives addresses of signatories and their witnesses; numbered
Identification.Title: "Conveyance of Premises known as The Kursaal, Bexhill"

Classification.Keyword: local history & De La Warr & Johnson & correspondence,1904

Identification.BriefDescription: a handwritten letter of two pages from the 8th Earl De La Warr from Grasse, France to Walter Claude Johnson telling him of his contacting his solicitor Mr.Cox about the proposed leasing by Mr.Johnson of Broadstone Farm; the Earl had been unable to contact E.J.Pape and had written two strong letters to him; the Earl invited Mr.Johnson to stay in his flat at Bexhill after his return to England on 10th January; a typed transcript of the Earl's letter is one of two typed sheets; the other is a copy of a letter sent to the Earl from Mr.Johnson; he excuses himself for a delay in replying having stayed in Tunbridge Wells for a rest without letter writing; he warns the Earl of Mr.Pape's influence, citing his own experience and the end of his friendship and business links with him; Mr.Johnson hoped to be in Bexhill on Monday 11th January but declined the invitation to shoot and stay at the Earl's flat

Classification.Keyword: local history & Johnson & Jackson & Kursaal & agreement,1916

Identification.BriefDescription: a document relating to entertainment at the Pavilion (Kursaal) in the summer of 1916, with related correspondence; (.1) a typed contract between W.Claude Johnson and Randell Jackson for the provision of entertainment at the Pavilion from 17th July 1916 for eight weeks; detail of terms in 10 paragraphs; signed by Randell Jackson on 12th July 1916; (.2) an unsigned, typed copy of a letter to Mr.Jackson dated 22nd August 1916 complimenting him on the earnings of the previous week; ends with a query about contracts of the artistes; probably sent from Mr. Pepper as agent for Mr.Johnson; (.3) a handwritten letter dated 23rd August 1916 addressed to Mr.Pepper and signed by Randell Jackson; he had arranged for an extra week of performances; he mentions the 'spell of brilliant weather'; (.4) a typed copy of a second letter dated 24th August 1916; the writer asks for a reply to his query in his previous letter about contracts of artistes; (.5) a handwritten letter dated 27th August 1916 and signed by Mr.Jackson; he mentions another good week and notes the anxiety of Mr.Pepper over contracts which Mr.Jackson has not given, asking whether there is a particular clause in the agreement giving cause; (.6) a typed copy of a letter dated 31st August; Mr.Pepper (presumably) had heard there were no contracts and in view of Clause 8 of the agreement was 'surprised'; he hoped Mr.Jackson would 'protect himself and Mr.Johnson'; clause 8 referred to artistes not appearing in Bexhill in 1917, unless with written consent of the proprietor, Mr.Johnson; (.7) a handwritten list of artistes in the Randell Jackson Company, with their addresses
Identification.Title: "Agreement for Entertainments at the Pavlion Bexhill-on-Sea"

Identification.BriefDescription: (.2)-(.9) 8 prints of local views produced by the Bexhill Observer from photographs taken at the turn of the 19th/20th C. in Bexhill and Little Common; 2 each of The Walnut Tree in the Old Town; High Street, Old Town; The Kursaal and De La Warr gates; and Blacksmith's Shop Little Common with the Wheatsheaf Inn; handwritten detail included from the original envelope gives the names of 'Crocker, Abbott and G.Dicks' for the Blacksmith's shop; (.1) a separate photograph of the walnut tree in leaf similar to the prints

Classification.Keyword: local history & Johnson & Kursaal/Pavilion & legal papers,1908+

Identification.BriefDescription: 2 boxes of documents dating from c.1908, when Walter Claude Johnson took possession of the Kursaal (later Bexhill Pavilion) from Lord De La Warr, until 1936 when Bexhill Pavilion Ltd was dissolved; included are accounts, legal documents associated with the High Court case in 1915, and a large bundle of correspondence when Bexhill Corporation was negotiating to buy the Pavilion in 1935-6; also included are some documents relating to the purchase of plots of land off Marina, by Mr.Frere and Mr. Cheesewiright
Identification.Title: "Bexhill Pavilion Boxes 1 and 2"

Description.Aspect: 2 boxes of documents whole some in folders
Description.Condition: varied; some documents very damaged by damp and insects; many worn and soiled

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & Pavilion & draft documents, 1924

Identification.Title: (.2) "Notice of Extraordinary General Meetings"

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill Pavilion Ltd & Parliament & petition,1925

Identification.BriefDescription: a typed copy of a petition to be given by Counsel to the House of Lords on behalf of Bexhill Pavilion Limited in the 1925 session; the company were against certain actions proposed in the Bexhill Corporation Bill before Parliament, especially in the case of the plan to provide entertainment in competition; it was maintained that the public provision would be paid for by the ratepayers; an attempt by the Corporation in 1920 to apply a compulsory purchase order on the Kursaal had failed; loss of business in respect of the Bill before Parliament would be unjust when much had been spent by the owners and plans for further refurbishment of the venue were underway; text arranged in numbered paragraphs giving detail of the Corporation's Bill before Bexhill Pavilion Limited's petition against it
Identification.Title: "Petition of the Bexhill Pavilion Ltd. Against By Counsel etc."

Description.Aspect: whole : 8 strong sheets; typed detail on one side of each; title on reverse of last sheet
Description.Condition: fair; very discoloured at top and bottom of front fold; crased and strongly folded; small tears into bottom edge of first 2 pages

Object.RelatedObject: 2011.17.83 pages of historical detail provided for counsel speaking for Bexhill Pavilion Limited contains list of all documents supplied for the petition

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & Corporation & Pavilion Co. & dispute,1925

Identification.BriefDescription: (.1) a series of letters or copies of letters, dated from April to May 1925, forming a correspondence about restrictions to building on land to the west of the Pavilion, formerly the Kursaal; the land was leased from the local council by Bexhill Pavilion Ltd. who had applied to build shops and bathing huts on the site; the restrictions dated from a document of 1899 when the De La Warr Estate was developing the area; one other letter refers to evidence to be given at a House of Commons Committee; (.2) 13 handwritten pages of a Legal Opinion dated 23rd September 1925 signed by Wilfrid M. Hunt of Lincoln's Inn
Identification.Title: "Bexhill Pavilion Ltd and Bexhill Corporation Correspondence as to Restrictive Covenants"
"Bexhill Pavilion Ltd Opinion"

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & Pavilion & entertainment & contract,1929+

Identification.BriefDescription: a bundle of letters or copies of letters forming correspondence between solicitors Langton and Passmore and their clients Bexhill Pavilion Ltd., or with Eric Ross, relating to contracts for entertainment at Bexhill Pavilion; dates range from 21st March 1929 to 17th February 1931; the first letter is from F.H.Pepper, from Bloomsbury Cinema Ltd., Southampton Row, London; after unrelated detail Mr.F.Pepper asks for an agreement with Mr.Ross to be prepared on the same basis as the previous year's; a letter of 20th January 1931 is from Harry S.Pepper, of Dix Ltd., Music Publishers of Charing Cross Road; certain amendments to the contract with Mr.Ross for the 1931 season had been agreed by Mr.Harry and Mr.Fred Pepper; the remaining letters indicate that the amendments were accepted and contracts signed; Mr Ross and his artistes would not appear in Bexhilll in 1932
Identification.Title: "Bexhill Pavilion Ltd and Eric Ross Esq. Correspondence"

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & Hewitt & shop & non-tenancy,1930

Identification.BriefDescription: a series of papers relating to the proposed hiring of a shop and chalet from Bexhill Pavilion Limited on land to the west of the Pavilion in 1930; (.1) a bundle of correspondence compiled by Langton and Passmore (see below); (.2)=(.4) copies of 2 letters from F.H.Pepper to Dorothy Hewitt and a letter in return, on notepaper headed as from 'Lavender Ladies', 11 Vale Road, Tunbridge Wells; (.5) (.6)2 drafts of a proposed contract between Miss Hewitt and Bexhill Pavilion Ltd. prepared at solicitors Langton and Passmore in Woolwich; (.1) the bundle of correspondence includes an instruction from Mr F.Pepper to Langton and Passmore to process the verbal agreement by Miss Hewitt to rent a shop near the Pavilion; letters to referees quoted by Miss Hewitt, their replies and acknowledgments to them; a letter from Miss Hewitt disputing Clauses 1 and 2 of the contract she had received for her approval; a reply by the solicitors on behalf of Bexhill Pavilion Ltd.; a final letter from G.Izzard, secretary for Miss Hewitt declining the proposed rent of the shop and chalet; Miss Hewitt had required Bexhill Pavilion Ltd. to arrange for painting and a door to be put in, between the shop and the chalet, for her year's contract, to be paid for by her should she not continue to rent the shop after that time; the amount payable, £90p.a. including rates and taxes was also disputed by the two parties

Description.Aspect: whole : 1 series of papers of various sizes fastened together at top l/h corner; 2 sheets of thin grey paper and 1 sheet of violet headed notepaper; 2 sets of three sheets each fastened at top l/h corner; mostly typed detail
Description.Condition: fair; some items, good; outer cover soiled and worn

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & Pavilion(Kursaal) & land & lease,1930

Identification.Title: "Lease of piece of land in the Parish of Bexhill, Sussex"

Identification.BriefDescription: correspondence relating to the lease of the Kursaal in 1914; (.1) a copy of a 3 page typed letter dated 9th January 1914 from Whale and Wates, solicitors for W.C.Johnson, confirming a telephone call with Mr.E.Gibson Cooney, of the Normanhurst Hotel, Bexhill and laying out in 12 paragraphs the conditions of a possible lease of the Kursaal; (.2) a handwritten letter on folded notepaper with printed heading dated 16th March 1914 explaining to Mr.Johnson that Mr.Cooney had failed to complete the lease but had introduced Mr.W.C.Pepper, willing to take on the lease and pay a year's rent in advance; a postscript mentions the enclosed reference received for Mr.Pepper; (.3) a handwritten letter from The Coast Development Corporation Ltd. dated 16th March 1914 replying to Whale and Wates and citing Mr.Pepper's contracts for the successful supply of entertainment on piers at various east coast of England resorts; (.4) a copy of a letter from Whale and Wates to Mr.Johnson dated 19th March 1914 enclosing an inventory for the Kursaal already discussed with Mr.Cooney; Mr.Pepper would be at the Kursaal to discuss the same the following day; the inventory was to be returned with notes in a distinctive colour; (.5) a copy of a letter from Whale and Wates to Mr.Johnson dated 21st March 1914; solicitors for Mr.Pepper had telephoned and indicated that their client had verbally agreed when discussing the inventory with Mr.Claude Horner Johnson, son of W.C.Johnson, not to lease the land adjacent to the Kursaal; this was thought to be a misunderstanding and clarification by Mr.Johnson Jr. was requested; (.6) a postcard with the printed address of Mr.Pepper at 3, Swallow Street, Piccadilly, London; a pencilled note dated 8th April 1914 is an acknowlegement of receipt of 2 safe keys of the Kursaal from Mr.Johnson

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & Kursaal & maintenance & correspondence,1914

Identification.BriefDescription: a bundle of letters and telegrams relating to difficulties in maintaining the roof and other necessary work on the Kursaal, Bexhill; dating from 31st March to 1th December 1914; the Bexhill contractor was Stephen Carey, of Haddocks Hill House; many letters and the telegrams are from Mr.Carey to Mr.Walter Claude Johnson, owner of the Kursaal; Mr.Johnson's replies are dated but informally handwritten; mention is made by Mr.Carey of the weather; the scouring of the beach below the Kursaal exposing the bases of the supporting piles; the breaking of the glass on the roof and dimensions of 6'2''x23" for one replacement section; the start of legal proceedings by the leaseholder Mr.Pepper in letter of 27th October; other work involved a faulty heating system put in by another contractor; an initial letter dated 31st March 1914 from Whale and Wates to Mr.Pepper includes the promised list of work to be done by Mr.Johnson on the signing of the lease

Description.Aspect: whole : a bundle of sheets of various dimensions; printed headings to many; handwritten and typed detail; most fastened together at topl/h corner; 5 separate and loose; loose title section
Description.Condition: fair; tightly folded; most securely fastened; water stained at one end of bundle; soiled

Object.Notes: an important set of letters for detail of the difficulties in trying to maintain the Kursaal building against the effects of the weather; to be viewed in association with the court case Johnson v Pepper adjudged in May 1915

Identification.BriefDescription: a series of letters copied mostly in one hand on strong sheets of paper; dating from 3rd April 1914 to 27th February 1915; correspondents are Whale and Wates, solicitors for W.C.Johnson, owner of the Kursaal; William C. Pepper, tenant of the Kursaal for the season; Kimber Bull and Duncan, solicitors for Mr.Pepper; and Mr. Stephen Carey, builder of Bexhill, carrying out works on the Kursaal structure; details of the letters concern the works promised to be carried out by the owner on completion of the lease of the Kursaal to Mr.Pepper; Mr.Pepper had expected to start his entertainment contracts earlier than was usual for the Bexhill summer season; no rent was paid in August; by September Mr Pepper was counting his losses, also affected by the international crisis, and intending to claim damages against the owner citing work delayed at the start of his expected season and for unsatisfactory maintenance to the building; by February 1915 the case was due for a court hearing in London

Description.Aspect: whole : 44 sheet of strong paper folded vertically; rusty remains of fastening at top l/h corner on some sheets; detail written mostly in same hand
Description.Condition: fair;soiled on outer surfaces; wear at lower edge of outer folded sheet

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & Kursaal & Johnson/Pepper & legal dealings,1914+

Identification.BriefDescription: a bundle of correspondence dating from 16th March 1914 to 13th May 1915; most of the letters are on headed notepaper from Kimber, Bull and Duncan, solicitors for William C.Pepper, leaseholder of the Kursaal from 30th March 1914; some letters are from Mr.Pepper; several items including telegrams are from Mr.Walter Claude Johnson, owner of the Kursaal, instructing his solicitors Whale and Wates; one letter is from James Glover; another from a representative of Frederick Hotels regarding licences; a query about the lease of the Kursaal was from a correspondent in Brighton; the matters dealt with were regarding the state of the Kursaal building when Mr.Pepper took on the lease, having seen only photographs from the former prospective leaseholder Mr.Gibson Cooney; interaction by telehone is mentioned; by April 1915 details of a legal settlement were dealt with including the surrender of the leases and agreements by Mr.Pepper, and payment of several amounts by Mr. Johnson; 2 sheets of pencilled notes are also included

Description.Aspect: whole : a bundle of correspondence; typed and handwritten detail;
Description.Condition: fair; whole bundle affected by water stains at bottom edge; side edges stained, damaged, soiled, worn and some torn; inside of sheets generally clean and legible, some quite fragile in places; handwritten or typed detail; some cards included

Identification.BriefDescription: a series of letters and a telegram dating from 17th April 1914 to 4th January 1915; (.1) dated 17th April 1914 from William C. Pepper, new tenant of the Kursaal, Bexhill, to Whale and Wates, solicitors for W.C.Johnson, owner of the Kursaal, complaining of promised maintenance work not yet done; (.9) dated 4th September 1914 from Kimber, Bull and Duncan, solicitors for Mr.Pepper, to Whale and Wates, citing breach of contract with reference to the promised maintenance, refusing payment expected from Mr.Pepper and mentioning damages due to him; (.11) a telegram dated 14th September 1914 from Stephen Carey to Mr.Johnson about drainage water causing serious trouble; (.11) a draft dated '15/9/14' in Mr.Johnson's handwriting of his reply to Mr.Carey on the same subject; (.12) a letter on business headed notepaper dated 16th September 1914 from Mr.Carey to Mr.Johnson explaining the drainage trouble; the outlet pipes ran down the sides of interior columns and were probably too small for the gutters; he would try to solve the problem and contact Mr.Johnson again if the proposed work proved to be expensive; the remaining letters are from Kimber, Bull and Duncan, mentioning a claim to the War Office and continuing breach of contract matters, including a writ to be served; (.21) dated 4th January 1915 states Mr.Pepper's desire to proceed with his own claim to the War Office and instructions to proceed with the legal action; unquoted letters add further detail to the ongoing complaint

Description.Aspect: whole : a bundle of papers of different sizes; mostly typewritten copies; business headings; 1 used telegram form
Description.Condition: fair; dark water stains at lower edges; worn at edges

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & Kursaal & maintenance & court case,1914+

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & Johnson & Kursaal & correspondence,1915

Identification.BriefDescription: 2 typewritten letters to Walter Claude Johnson from his solicitors Whale and Wates; (.1) dated 9th January 1915 updates Mr.Johnson after a meeting with Mr.Pepper, plaintiff in the legal action being prepared regarding the Kursaal maintenance; it is suggested that evidence be sought as to the financial situation of previous leaseholders such as Mr.Glover and Mr.Johnson's son during their seasons; other information could be found in local newspapers regarding the emntertainments provided during the 1914 season by Mr.Pepper; (.2) dated 30th March 1915 thanks Mr.Johnson for his letter of 26th March; since Mr.Pepper would not pay rent or insurance as regards the Kursaal it was important for the mortgage that the insurance be renewed within the time available; official notification was enclosed and a cheque for £45 expected in due course, from Mr.Johnson

Description.Aspect: 2 sheets with printed heading and typed detail fastened at top l/h corner whole 1 similar single sheet
Description.Condition: good; slight soiling and discoloration

Identification.BriefDescription: a group of related papers kept together;(.1) and (.6)=(.9) are officially published and printed 'Statements of Claim' delivered 21st January 1915 for the case between Pepper, plaintiff, and Johnson, defendant, in the Chancery Division of the High Court before Mr.Justice Warrington; pencilled notes added in (.6); receipt note on front of (.1) signed for K B and D; (.2) is a neatly written list of requirements set out by Whale and Wates in a letter to Mr.Johnson on 9th January 1915 [see related record below]; (.3) typed copy of a letter dated 21st August 1914 to Whale and Wates from Kimber Bull and Duncan stating reasons for non payment of sums agreed by their client, Mr.Pepper; (.4) a typed copy of a letter dated 24th August 1914 from K B and D to W and W suggesting that their clients should meet to resolve matters between them; (.5) is a small sheet of handwritten notes dated '17/9/14', of dates and instances of flooding of the Kursaal from 31st May to 11/12th of September 1914; a note at the bottom in pencil states, 'WCJ will arrange with Pepper direct to go down'
Identification.Title: "Statement of Claim"

Identification.BriefDescription: research by George Whale, solicitor for Walter Claude Johnson, prospective investor in the Kursaal, Bexhill, relating to the financing of the De La Warr estate; (.1) a typed copy of a document describing as by an indenture of 1st January 1889 the entail of the De la Warr estate from March 1854; the 7th Earl De La Warr and his eldest son, Lionel Charles Cranfield Sackville, Viscount Cantelupe, recently come of age, assign the estate to J.A.M.Cope and A.M.Cope as trustees; (.2) a handwritten list of charges on the De La Warr estate made under both settlements of 1877 and 1889; (.2) notes mentioning a Liver mortgage which includes a full list of charges on the settled estates; (.4) notes on the ongoing negotiations for the sale of the Kursaal to a newly formed company in which Earl De Warr and Mr.Johnson would be shareholders

Object.Notes: Para 1 : ...."the Earl will ...cause to be conveyed to the Company hereinafter mentioned by all necessary and proper parties for £7375 ...... all that land and buildings known as the Kursaal at Bexhill on Sea (as shown on the annexed plan) {annotation : Messrs C and L annex amended plan} together with sufficient acess thereto from existing public ways."; Para 2 : ...the Earl in order to provide part of the purchase money will procure and the Company will execute a first Mortgage on such Kursaal for £5000 at a rate of interest not exceeding £4.....that such Mortgage shall not be called in for at least 5 years from the date thereof."; Para 5 : ... £2000 shall be in paid up shares (half of which shares shall be allotted to the Earl or his nominee and the other half to the Purchaser or his nominee) £3000 further part...shall be found and paid to Stanislaus Wurms..."

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & Kursaal & sale & company,1906

Identification.BriefDescription: a typed copy of a letter dated 30th August 1906 from Cope and Co., trustees of the De La Warr estate, to Cox and Lafone, solicitors for the 8th Earl De La Warr; included is a clarification of the amount to be paid to the Trustees by the Earl for the purchase of the Kursaal to enable the formation of the proposed company; a draft mortgage for £5000 agreed by the Trustees was sent with the letter along with a draft mortgage transfer from Col. Tredcroft and Major Buckley of the money advanced to build the Kursaal; of the builders so far disregarded, one, Noakes, had died bankrupt; the other, Young, might agree to act through his solicitor but this would delay proceedings; the Trustees would require from the Earl's solicitors the Abstract of Title from the 1901 mortgage from the Dowager Countess De La Warr; the Observations on the Answers to the Requisitions written by George Whale, solicitor for Mr. Johnson, prospective partner in the company, were not important and not fully understood by Cope and Co.

Description.Aspect: 2 sheets fastened at top l/h corner whole typed detail on one side of each
Description.Condition: fair; damaged at top edge; small dark stain bottom of vertical fold

Cope and Co. (De La Warr Trustees)

Identification.BriefDescription: a copy of a letter dated 27th September 1906 from Cope and Co., trustees of the De La Warr estate, to George Whale, solicitor for Walter Claude Johnson, prospective partner and shareholder in the proposed Kursaal Company Ltd.; the first paragraph complains that the draft conveyance received with Mr.Whale's letter the previous day was, as revised by Mr.Whale's Counsel, a restoration of the original which they had amended in consultation with their Counsel; it was pointed out that Mr.Whale's client was not party to the dealings between the De La Warr Trustees and the 8th Earl and their Counsel had no right to criticise them; the letter continues in this vein stating the views of Cope and Co., ending with the hope that the matter which had dragged on for so long should be resolved, or the transaction must be reconsidered

Identification.BriefDescription: an envelope containing several sheets of detail relating to the final arrangements for the handing over of the Kursaal from Earl de La Warr to Walter Claude Johnson; (.1) 4 copies of letters dated 13th March (2), 17th and 18th July 1907 regarding money exchanged in the sale of the Kursaal; (.2) a typed copy of a letter dated 25th July in which Mr.Johnson agress to give to Lord De La Warr his mining rights over Buckhurst estate and Ashdown Forest, with 10% interest should they be sold on by the Earl; (.3) original handwritten notes under 5 headings titled 'Kursaal - Last arrangements' on notepaper of the Royal Societies Club St.James's Street, London SW dated 18th August 1907; attached is a typed version with additional handwritten notes, and a blank covering sheet; (.4) a small sheet of handwritten notes in similar hand to (.3) mentioning Countess De La Warr receiving £700
Identification.Title: "Kursaal Last Arrangements"

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & pavilion & petition & brief,1925

Identification.BriefDescription: 20 large pages of typed detail giving the position of Bexhill Pavilion Ltd. for the consideration of Mr.H.St.John Digby Raikes, K.C., as Counsel for the Company in their petition against the Bexhill Corporation Bill, to be heard in the House of Lords in the 1925 Session; one part only of a package of documents and letters presented to Counsel and listed on first page; pp1=17 summarise in detail the negotiations over about 15 years between the owners of the Pavilion and Bexhill Corporation, represented by Mayors and Town Clerk, Mr.T.E.Rodgers; lack of improvement of the buildings is put down to the resulting uncertainty; the Petition is against the proposals of the Corporation in the Bill to purchase property and provide entertainment through the rates, in competition with the Pavilion; pp 18=20 are a personal statement by Mr.G.L Wates, solicitor, of his involvement with the Pavilion since its purchase as the Kursaal by his client Walter Claude Johnson from Earl De La Warr in 1908
Identification.Title: "Bexhill Corporation Bill - Brief in Support of a Petition of Bexhill Pavilion Limited under their Common Seal against the Bill"

Description.SummaryText: whole : 21 strong sheets fastened securely at top l/h corner; typed detail on first side of each, with title on reverse of last blank sheet; underlining of detail throughout with additional comments in margins
Description.Condition: fair; outer surface and edges soiled and slightly worn

RelatedObject.Note: printed Minutes of Proceedings of House of Commons Local Legislation Committee 23rd July 1925 re - Bexhill Corporation Bill

Object.Notes: last words of Mr.Wates' personal statement : " - but private enterprise can and will supply the needs of Bexhill if given a fair chance and reasonable security of tenure."

Identification.BriefDescription: a copy of a memorandum sent to the Town Clerk of Bexhill on 19th May 1926 describing the property of Bexhill Pavilion Limited; the Pavilion had been 'entirely rebuilt', with seating capacity for 1000; the adjoining Winter Garden had communicating doors and could provide 300 to 400 more seats; winter revenue had already been considerable; new, up-to-date lavatories were available to patrons and the public, bringing more 'substantial' revenue; a summary of the property held by the company precedes the detailed description (for which please see below in Notes)
Identification.Title: "Bexhill Pavilion Limited - Memorandum descriptive of the property sent to Town Clerk, Bexhill 19.5.26"

Freehold land to the East with fourteen permanent Beach Huts thereon; 4. Leasehold Land to the West with eight Beach Huts and other buildings thereon; 5. Freehold land further to the West at present occupied for Tea Gardens, site of movable Beach Huts etc. etc.

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & Pavilion & directors & meeting & minutes,1928

Identification.BriefDescription: typed minutes of a meeting of directors of Bexhill Pavilion Ltd. held in London on 22nd November 1928; present were Mr.Harry Pepper and Mr.G.Leslie Wates, with Mr.R.Hopwood, solicitor, Mr.W.B.Anderson, accountant, and Mr.F.H.Pepper, manager of the Pavilion; the first resolution was to appeal against the new rate assessments; the second, to seek removal of restrictive covenants on the property owned; the third, to appoint Mr.Fred Pepper as secretary of the company; the fourth resolution, to borrow £10,000 from Max Limited to discharge a loan from Barclays Bank, a debenture being issued to be used as security; a last resolution was to borrow a further £1,000 from Bloomsbury Cinema Ltd.
Identification.Title: "Minutes of the Meeting of the Board of Directors of Bexhill Pavilion Limited"

Description.SummaryText: whole : 2 sheets of duplicated typed detail fastened at top l/h corner

Identification.BriefDescription: a working draft of a debenture issue of £10,000 at 6% p.a. following the resolution by the directors of Bexhill Pavilion Limited on 22nd November 1928; to be used as security for a loan from Max Ltd of 71 Powis Street, Woolwich, repayable on 31st December 1934; typed detail annotated in pencil and amended in black ink; draft dated 30th October 1928; completed draft dated 3rd December 1928
Identification.Title: "Bexhill Pavilion Limited -Completed Draft Debenture 30.10.28"

Identification.BriefDescription: a large bundle of correspondence dated from 1931 to 1937 filed and preserved by G.Leslie Wates of Langton and Passmore (London) incorporating Whale and Wates of Woolwich, solicitors for Bexhill Pavilion Limited; arranged in chronological order; very varied as to subject matter, but generally presenting the story behind the final years of Bexhill Pavilion, including negotiations with Bexhill Corporation and Earl De La Warr, Mayor in 1935; an additional small bundle of loose papers relating to the correspondence and including newspaper cuttings (recorded separately); this final correspondence and whole document collection reveal the extent to which the involvement in the business of Bexhill Pavilion Limited of a conscientious Mr.Wates had grown since his practising with Mr.George Whale, solicitor for Walter Claude Johnson, in Woolwich at the turn of the century; Mr.Johnson died in 1928, his executors remaining involved to the end

Description.SummaryText: whole : a large bundle of papers, fastened at top l/h corner; a smaller bundle of separate papers including newsprint
Description.Condition: fair; some papers discoloured or stained where exposed during storage; some edges torn or worn; legibility, good

Object.Notes: as a file of solicitor's correspondence it comprises more and less significant communications, from long explanations to simple acknowledgments; frequent correspondents are Harry Pepper, sending local newscuttings, and Fred Pepper, manager of the Pavilion, reporting on the success or otherwise of the Pavilion entertainment and the situation in Bexhill; later correspondence, noted 'Confidential', is between Mr.Wates and S.J.Taylor, Town Clerk for Bexhill, during discreet negotiations; this also covers the trouble caused by Mr.Ravenshear after the sale of the Pavilion; included is a carbon copy of a 4 page typed letter dated 1 Mar 1935 from Mr.Wates to the 9th Earl De La Warr, Mayor of Bexhill, at the Ministry of Agriculture; 2 letters at the end of the correspondence are from Fred Pepper to Mr.Wates, 26 Apr 1936 sincerely thanking him for all his help during his time as Manager of the Pavilion, and, 26 May 1937, saying that it had been arranged by Mr.Yorke, producer, that he and his wife should be back working in Bexhill for the season, and commenting on the sudden death of Charles Talbot; Mr.Wates' reply dated 4 Jun 1936 mentions their business association over 22 years when Fred's brother Will was alive and later with Harry (Pepper); he expects Fred to return eventually to run the new (DLW) Pavilon after a season's rest; Mr.Wates hoped not to lose touch and offered any help Fred might need at any time
Object.RelatedObject: BEXHM : 2011.17.112.2=31 records for the loose papers in Bundle 9

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & Ravenshear & letter & circular, 1936

Identification.BriefDescription: (.1) a long letter dated 12th November 1936 published as a circular to the Ratepayers of Bexhill by the author, Councillor George Ravenshear of South Cliff House, Bexhill; intended as a 'Letter to the Editor' of the 'Bexhill Observer', it was 'received too late for publication' and would need to be be published only in parts; Councillor Ravenshear criticised in detail the Corporation's financial dealings and the recent increase in rates after the building of the De La Warr Pavilion and purchase of the old Pavilion; his experience in business had led him to offer his services to the Finance Committee but a vote had gone against him, 'a want of courtesy' in his opinion; (.2) a circular printed letter to the Electors of Central Ward dated 23rd November 1936; having been re-elected himself on 2nd November, he urged the electors to vote for Mr.W.H.Hughes as 'a man of mature and extensive business experience and ability' who would support Councillor Ravenshear in his efforts to get value for money and reduce the rates of 9s 10d in the pound
Identification.Title: "The Policy of the Bexhill Corporation and Accounts for the year ending March, 1936"

Identification.BriefDescription: a copy on thin paper of the abstract of title of Mr.Thomas Wightman Dexter, builder, and purchaser of land in Clifford Road, Bexhill; the recital of ownership starts with the purchase of the land on 29 May 1897 by Albert Christopher Dawes Hicks, architect and surveyor of Bexhill, and vendor to Mr.Dexter in September 1897; vendors to Mr.Hickes were the Prudential Assurance Company, the 8th Earl De La Warr and his trustees Alfred Buckley and Charles Tredcroft; detail of the first indenture quoted is that of settlement of 30th January 1877; further indentures quoted are listed in the final part of the document with dates and names of parties, such as trustees and those deceased over time; part of the text referring to conditions of purchase on page 2 to 3 is bracketed and annotated in pencil for further use; a plan originally attached after page 3 has been removed leaving page 4 and the title sheet separate
Identification.Title: "Abstract of Title of Mr.Thomas W.Dexter to land in Clifford Road, Bexhill-on-Sea"

Identification.BriefDescription: a poster urging the voters of Bexhill who had signed a protest after a Great Indignation Meeting at the York Hall on June or July 19th 1896 to use their vote to avoid the 'scandalous proceedings' of the previous year; on the reverse is a list of names of residents, arranged under names of roads in both new and old areas of the town, who had signed to protest at the proposed unsettling of an agreement of 16th December 1895 between the District Council and the De La Warr Estate; printed and published in London by Chas. Straker and Sons for the election of District Councillors on 5th April 1897

Description.SummaryText: whole : a poster printed on both sides
Description.Condition: fair
Description.Note: one side mostly covered in sticky backed plastic; signs of display at corners

Object.Notes: Text of the signed protest : 'To the Chairman and members of the Bexhill Urban District Council - We, the undersigned Owners and Ratepayers of the Urban District of Bexhill hear with great regret, that it is proposed to unsettle the agreement between the District Council and the De La Warr Estate embodied in the Council's resolution of December 16th, 1895, and we are very deeply convinced that the present and future prosperity of the Town is dependent on the agreement being sustained.'

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & 1200 Charter year & planning & stationery,1972

Identification.BriefDescription: items relating to the planning and administration of the celebrations of 1200th year of the Bexhill Charter in 1972; (.1) a letter dated 15th March 1971 from the 'advisory panel' secretary, R.A.Lockwood, addressed to Mr.H.J.Sargent at Bexhill Museum introducing the proposed celebrations and giving names of those on the Advisory Panel; those receiving the letter were to reply with ideas for their participation by 31st May 1971; (.2) a typed sheet of guidance for local organisations and individuals including the structure of the administration of the project; (.3)=(.5) 3 tickets for the service of praise and dedication at St.Peter's Church on 9th April 1972 each with blank space for the ticket holders' names; (.6) an official blank invitation from The Mayor and The Rector of Bexhill to the service at St.Peter's Church on 9th April; (.7)(.8) 2 small folded sheets of blue printed detail about the Charter Celebrations including the official design for the event, an historical synopsis and names of officials on the Advisory Panel; (.9)=(.11) 3 official booklets issued for the celebrations with details of the events and names of those involved, including Princess Alexandra as guest of honour

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & Longley Bros. & correspondence,1958

Identification.BriefDescription: a plain postcard addressed to Mr. Longley, drapers, Bexhill, with handwritten message on reverse: 'Dear Sir, is your interest in Bar maids and Beer -? OR would you be willing to let the public use the sun lounge in the De La Warr Pavilion? Can you do anything to get them open to the public. Plenty of room for a bar in the Foyer and let the people have the Sun - it was designed for public use, not Bar maids'; no signature or name of sender; dated 17 March 1958 (St. Patrick's day)

Description.SummaryText: whole : a plain postcard with address and stamp on one side and message on reverse
Description.Condition: fair

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & Penguin Players & production & material,1950+

Identification.BriefDescription: a collection relating to the Penguin Players or Theatre South East, Repertory Companies performing in Bexhill from 1950 to 1975 and their director, Richard Burnett, supported by his wife Peggy Paige; (.1)=(.7) 7 typewritten scripts for plays and pantomimes and a tied bundle of manuscript and printed piano music associated with 'Jack and The Beanstalk; (.8) 49 x DLWP programmes for performances during summer seasons 1973 to 1975, including regular actor Michael Rooney; (.9) 14 x programmes for performances 1967=9, 1971 and 1973 connected with Richard Burnett in Eastbounre, Folkestone, Croydon and Cambridge theatres; (.10) a commemorative booklet issued in 1960 for the ten years of performing in Bexhill; (.11) a photograph of Richard Burnett in forces uniform with Peggy Paige; (.12) a letter dated 25th August 1942 to Harry Hanson, Esq. from the Lord Chamberlain's Office about changes previously required to a play script 'The Bachelor Father' licensed in 1929; (.13) a programme for Penguin Players performanaces of 'Two Dozen Red Roses' at the Egerton ParkTheatre from Mon 29 June 1959

Description.SummaryText: whole : 63 folded sheets with printed detail on each (programmes); 1 booklet with cover featuring portrait photographs on pink background; 1 sheet of headed notepaper with typed detail; 1 postcard sized photograph4 folders containing sheets of typed detail; a book of typewritten sheets stapled into a buff-coloured paper cover; 2 sets of stapled sheets of typed detail in orange paper covers; 1 tied bundle in two buff-coloured card covers containing handwritten detail on manuscript sheets and copies of published music
Description.Condition: fair

Object.Notes: play scripts by Leslie Sturgess are 'Pride and Prejudice' marked for Mrs. Bennett, and 'Jane Eyre' copy no. 9: pantomime scripts by Richard Burnett of 'Sinbad the Sailor', copies 12 and 16; 'Cinderella', 'Dick Whittington and his Cat' and 'Jack and the Beanstalk'; the repertory company was affected by the changes of local government in 1974, when Bexhill Borough was taken into Rother District Council; the last performance on 28th October 1975 at the De La Warr Pavilion was the 1011th and final production of the Penguin Players

Identification.BriefDescription: a booklet issued as a Souvenir Programme for the Fifth Annual Festival of Music promoted by Bexhill Corporation; events took place from 27th to 31st July 1964; leading performers were the Halle Orchestra under chief conductor Sir John Barbirolli and associate conductors, Lawrence Leonard and Maurice Handford; all the members of the Halle Orchestra are listed on p.4; Wednesday's concert featured Jazz from Johnny Dankworth and Ken Colyer, and Folk Songs by The Spinners; the daily events were similar to that of previous Festivals of Music, including the Divine Service and Civic Procession on the first day

Identification.BriefDescription: a souvenir programme for the 6th Festival of Music promoted by Bexhill Corporation; events took place from 26th to 30th July 1965; in a red paper cover with minimum design on front; performers over the five days were the Halle Orchestra, the Bournemouth Symphony Orchestra and the BBC Concert Orchestra under conductors Sir John Barbirolli, Rudolph Schwarz and Vilem Tausky; solo pianist was Julius Katchen; daily events were similar to previous festivals of Music; menus for pre-concert dinners are on p. 4

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & DLWP & 8th Festival of Music & programme,1967

Identification.BriefDescription: a souvenir programme for the Eighth Festival of Music promoted by Bexhill Corporation; events took place from Wednesday 5th to Sunday 9th July 1967; performers included the Halle Orchestra conducted by Sir John Barbirolli and Maurice Handford, the London Mozart Players conducted by Harry Blech. and the Band of the Scots Guards conducted by Captain J.H.Howe; daily events followed similar programmes to those of previous Festivals of Music; soloists of note were Janet Baker, contralto, John Ogden, pianist, Michael Davis, violinist and leader of the Halle Orchestra, David Mason, trumpeter; inside the back cover is a list of dates and soloists appearing with the Pavilion Concert Orchestra at Sunday concerts, and artistes performimg in the Stars Charity Show on 27th August

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & DLWP & 15th Festival of Music & programme,1974

Identification.BriefDescription: a leaflet giving details of the 15th Bexhill Annual Festival of Music from Friday 24th to Tuesday 28th May; each day's programme of events is listed in one column; a booking form was included; The Halle Orchestra performed concerts on Saturday and Sunday evenings; the DaSilva Puppet Theatre performed two children's events on Friday, including 'Peter and The Wolf'; Miki and Griff performed 'Country Fever' on Monday evening, and a piano recital by Craig Sheppard took place on Tuesday evening; a recital of Baroque Music from the (European) Common Market took place in Manor House Barn on Friday evening, and Josef Hofer and his Viennese Ensemble played twice each day on the Sun Terrace on Monday and Tuesday; the usual lectures and outings were organised and full daily menus given for 6pm dinners; promoters were Rother Distruct Council

Identification.BriefDescription: 3 souvenir programmes for the Bexhill Autumn Festivals of Light Music in 1968, 1969 and 1971; the first day's evening performance was a BBC broadcast of 'Friday Night is Music Night' by the BBC Concert Orchestra and various soloists; another concert by the BBC Concert Orchestra took place on Saturday evening in 1968 and 1969, with a third concert on the Sunday in 1971; other performers were the Palm Court Orchestra - Grand Hotel, with Reginald Leopold (1968) and the Neil Feiling Orchestra; concerts took place at the De La Warr Pavilion and other daily events such as talks, pre concert dinners and post concert dancing were similar to those of the Festivals of Music hedl in the summer; the Light Music festivals were presented by Bexhill Corporation and the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC)

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & Charter Year & Princess Alexandra & visit & programme,1972

Identification.BriefDescription: a programme issued for the visit of HRH Princess Alexandra to Bexhill on 9th April 1972 to commemorate the granting of the Charter by King Offa in 772AD to endow a church in Bexhill, around which developed the village and later town; HRH arrived at 3pm by helicopter at the De La Warr Pavilion and was driven to St. Peter's Church; an Order of Service is included in the booklet; many details are given about those taking part in the proceedings in any way; later, HRH would unveil a commemorative Ironwork panel at the Old Manor House, leaving Bexhill after 5.30pm; the coat of arms of Bexhill is analysed as is the Charter symbol; details of the part-broadcast evening concert by the BBC Concert Orchestra are given

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & Grammar School & Edwards & memorabilia,1960+

Identification.BriefDescription: a small collection of varied items mostly connected to Gordon Edwards (1929=2012), teacher and tenor soloist, by his handwritten detail; (.1) a celebratory, gold covered booklet for the Golden Jubilee of Bexhill Grammar School 1926-1976; history of the schools in text and illustrations; (.2) a programme for a performance of Handel's 'Messiah' on Good Friday 15th April 1960 by Bexhill Choral Society at the De la Warr Pavilion; includes detail of officers of the society and the words of the oratorio as sung and published by Novello and Co. Ltd.; (.3)(.4) 2 sheets with typed detail, one dated July 1965, expressing in verse Mr. Edwards' desperation about writing endless reports; (.5) a folded card with printed detail of a programme of events for the Coffee Pot Club, Bexhill, in Autumn 1964; (.6) a booklet published in 1966 by the Borough of Hastings for the anniversary of the Battle of Hastings in 1066; describes 'The Hastings Embroidery', an exhibition of panels of embroidery illustrating the most important events in British history; panels worked for the borough by the Royal School of Needlework; (.7) a press cutting from 'T'he Toronto Star' of 15th February 2000 reporting on a book published by Alfred Bader of letters written to him by his future wife, Isabel Overton, a fellow Canadian met at sea in 1949, but married 32 years later; includes a current photograph of the couple; handwritten comment added by Mr. Edwards, 'Answered'; (.8 a coloured photograph taken by Gordon Edwards of a steam car at the 4th Annual 'Bexhill 100' car show in May 1994; (.9)=(.12) postcard size coloured photographs of Bexhill sea front with handwritten detail on reverse7yyyyy7\
Identification.Title: Gordon Edwards Collection

Description.SummaryText: whole : a small collection consisting of a large gold covered booklet; 2 folded sheets stapled as a printed booklet; 2 sheets wth typed detail on each; a folded card; a 60 page booklet with blue and yellow printed design on white front; a newspaper cutting with photograph; and 5 postcard size photographs
Description.Condition: good
Description.SummaryText: (.1) large booklet, cover worn;

Object.Notes: associated records BEXHM : 2019.70 placed in same folder

Identification.CollectionName: Bexhill Olde Time Musc Hall Society memorabilia

Object.Notes: Christening gown owned by Mrs James Gwynne who lived at Folkington Manor, Polegate, her son Neville wore this gown. He was the brother of Roland whose name is on a plaque with other names. He raised money for Eastbourne's Bandstand. Neville later lived at Deans Farm, Piddinghoe and has a plaque in the village hall. There are family connections to the book 'Violet' by Jessica Douglas-Home

Acquisition.Conditions: Mrs Ewen is one of the sisters of The servants with Jesus

Object.Notes: The dolls were costumed in 1972 by: Miss Elsie Eames, Miss Ethel Sawyer and Mrs Winifred Chapman. These dolls were dressed in the style of 772 AD for an exhibition in the De La Warr Pavilion. These depicted King Offa with his royal household giving the Charter to Bishop Oswald and his monks. A group of Saxon villagers were in the background. They were donated to The Servants with Jesus, The Coach House, Manor Gardens, Bexhill in 1978.

Classification.Keyword: local history & Bexhill & DLWarr & return & prog.,1900

Identification.BriefDescription: an official programme for Earl De La Warr's Reception at Bexhill after the South African Campaign on 25th July 1900; organised by a Welcoming Committee, chairman Councillor Daniel Mayer; the event began at noon with the arrival of guests followed by luncheon at 1p.m. at the Hotel Metropole; music was to be played in Station Square before the arrival of the train from St.Leonards with the Earl and Countess De La Warr; a 15 gun salute was to be fired before the official civic welcome; a procession listed in the booklet proceeded to the Town Hall; from there around the new town streets before returning via Belle Hill and High Street to the Manor House Grounds where the schoolchildren of the town were to be given tea
Identification.Title: "Earl De La Warr's Reception at Bexhill"

Description.Aspect: 10 pages in a buff coloured cover whole cover design and interior text and pictures all printed in sepia
Description.Condition: fair; cover worn at stapling; staples rusting; back cover repaired with vertical paper strip

Boxall at the Enquiry on 13th and 14th December 1900 in the Council Chamber before C.N. Cresswell, Commissioner of Her Majesty's Privy Council; much annotated, and signed with financial detail by W.P.G.Boxall; includes the petition itself and contributions from 13 witnesses
Identification.Title: "Brief for the Petitioners"

Person.Note: from : Funnel, Barry : 30 Silchester Road, St. Leonards

Acquisition.Conditions: The copyright belongs to Hastings Museum

Object.Notes: The following is typed on a card with the photos: "Bexhill in the late 18th century. In the latter years of his life, Francis Grose (1731-1791) toured the British Isles making small sketches of places and scenes that interested him. Ten large volumes of his work are in the British Museum. In 1972 a sketch-book of Groses's tour of East Sussex unexpectedly turned up at an aution sale and was acquired for the Hastings Museum by Mr. John Manwaring Baines. With Mr. Baines' permission, Mr Barry Funnell photographed the sketches and these are the pictures relating to Bexhill. The captions are those recorded in the sketch-book, followed by Mr. Funnell's explanatory notes where appropriate." Curator's comment: These is some reason to doubt if these were painted by Grose, some pictures show the Bexhill Barracks which were built on 1798, this is seven years after Grose died!
